text: Ten plastic folding chairs line the hallway -- all empty except for one. In the last chair sits Mary Horowitz, 31, in her best synthetic cardigan, somebody's grandmother's skirt, her o red rubber boots. Genius meets retard. She mumbles to herself.
Four letter word for... vomit. She takes a deep breath to calm her nerves. it doesn't he

Not "barf". For sure not "barf". That's too easy. "Puke" is okay, but maybe a bit pedestrian (that means boring)... I like "hurl". I do. I like the way it rolls off your tongue -- the word, I mean. But my all time favorite is none of those. She puts her head between her knees, tries to keep it together. 2.
Four letter word for vomit? S-P-E- W. Spew... Sp-ew. A door nearby opens but Mary doesn't budge. A POLICE OFFI walks out. A 40ish female TEACHER pokes her head out the door, signa to Mary.
We're ready for you now. (a plastic Kroger shopping Mary jumps up, grabs her purse bag).
Jesus help me.
Mary stands in front of the chalkboard, "CAREER DAY" writ in huge letters behind her. She smiles with terror at the class of 10 year old KIDS. The Teacher reads from her notes.

Here's a treat, students. Our final guest for Career Day, Miss Mary Horowitz, is the crossword constructor for the Atlanta Citizen. You know the crossword puzzles you see every week in the newspaper? It's her job to create them. Isn't that fun? Mary stares at the Teacher, whispers.
You weren't supposed to tell them.
Pardon me?
I made a crossword puzzle to help them guess what my job is. You ruined it.
Oh, I'm so sorry. 3. Mary takes the crossword puzzles out of her bag, looks at them like lost puppies.
Maybe you could tell them a bit about what your job is like? watche s hit
Mary drops thu p file out her the bottom She p lls u hearsed enthusiasm. bag, reads with re

People do crossword puzzles all the time but they don't often think of the person who made all the words fit together, and who thought up the clues, and who made sure the little black squares at the top mirror the ones at the bottom. She pulls one of the crosswords out of the garbage can, h it up, turns it upside down, forces a nervous smile.

Crossword constructors usually have above average intelligence, with knowledge of just about every subject you can imagine. And it helps if they can spell. The card in Mary's hand reads "LAUGH". She laughs. Nobody else does. She looks at the cards again, instantly gets serious, sweeps her hand through the air.
Imagine, for a moment, a world without crossword puzzles. A world- Mary notices one Kid with his hand up. It totally throws off.
Daniel, you have a question?
You make a living doing that? Just making puzzles? The Atlanta Citizen only comes out on Fridays. One puzzle a week can't make you enough to live on. A LARGE KID in the front row pipes up. 4.
How do you pay your rent?
My parents -
You live with your parents? The Kids all laugh their asses off. Mary just stares at them.
Oh my God, how old are you? Still living at home! The kids all laugh some more. Mary's on the verge of pani
Children! The Teacher shoots the Kids a warning look, then notices hyperventilating.
Are you okay? Mary grasps for breath, struggles to speak.
Water.
Water. Just hang on. The Teacher rushes out. The kids all stare at Mary.
Yep, I live at home... She forces herself to get it together, totally faking it.

But so do all of you, so there... And sure, I only create one crossword puzzle a week but I have deadlines, I have stress, I have demands on me so huge you would not believe. The newspaper business is hell. I mean it. Hell. Somebody's got to write about all the horrors that go on in this world.

MARY (cont'd) And after people read about those horrors, somebody else has to bring them back from the brink of suicide. Who do you think that is? She leans in close to the front row, scares herself more anybody.

Me! My crossword puzzle is always good news. it enlightens. it r andma's entertains. It keeps your g mind alive so she remembers to send you five bucks on your birthday. Think about that as you lie in bed tonight picking your nose and crying yourself to sleep. I know I will. The Kids just stare at her. She leans against the teacher desk, tries to look relaxed but fails miserably.
My job matters, you know. In media circles I am, as the Dutch say, geliefd. That means I have plenty of friends. Hoards, in fact. Scads even. The kids aren't buying it.

You're a freak. The kids all nod in agreement. Mary's frozen, devastated. The Teacher rushes back into the room with a cup of water hands it over. Mary sips it like communion wine. Half of runs down her chin. Mary looks at the Teacher, fakes a smile.
That's a pretty blouse. The Teacher smiles back. Awkward.
The front doors of the school swing open and a visibly sh Mary walks out. She takes a deep breath and embraces deni 6.
Twelve letter phrase for smashing success! She heads down the walkway toward the bus stop.
As one would say in old Paris... Coup de maitre! A CUSTODIAN cleaning the school yard looks up. Mary keeps talking - now to him.

It means "master stroke", even though the direct translation is actually "master blow"... Leave it to the French to pass off an unpleasant slave activity as an everyday expression. The Custodian doesn't know what the hell she's talking ab Mary continues on to the bus stop.
The CITY BUS DRIVER watches as Mary pays her $1.75 one ni at a time.
I sometimes suffer from benign positional vertigo. Could you please not drive until I'm - f He ignores her, starts driving. Mary struggles toward t back o f the bus, grabbing g goes.

Excuse me... pardonnez-moi... begnadiyen sie mich... She lurches for an empty seat and just about dislodges he shoulder on the center pole. Finally settled, she peeks under her sweater at the shoulder damage.
Hello hematoma. She smiles at an angry ELDERLY LADY sitting across from h The lady gives her the "don't talk to me" glare, then sta out the window. Mary fidgets in her seat. 7.

In crosswords, as in life, some days are harder than others. It's true. In the New York Times, for example, the puzzles get harder as the week goes. So on Monday, a day that traditionally bites the big one, the crossword is super easy. It's comforting to know that although life can be difficult at times, crosswords let you off easy when you need it the most. Mary looks around for anybody to talk to. The other PASSENGERS avert their eyes. Mary starts biting her nails

A frail 80 year old man MR. TAKIHASHI works alongside his wspapers, 40ish granddaughter BETTY selling magazines, ne smokes and Pocky. In the corner of the newsstand, a muted TV features CNN "Breaking News" coverage of a high speed car chase. BUSINESSMEN are glued to the images as they wait in line. Mary grabs a half a dozen different newspapers, yells to Takihashi like he's deaf.
He ignores her. Mary hands the papers to Betty.
Hi Betty. Betty just rings up the papers.

Did you see the review of "Hairspray" in the Journal yesterday? They used the word "spectacular" -- always a good sign. Maybe you'd like to go see it with rne? I have a coupon for five dollars off. Betty shoves the newspapers back across the counter, poin at them, then speaks in barely recognizable English. S.
Nine dollar twenty. Mary fishes in her bag for money.

We could bring your dad if you want. I don't think the show is ageist. That means he won't feel like a loser for being old. As she takes her time paying, Mr. Takihashi madly gesture about Mary holding up the line. Betty barks at her.
Pecha kucha! Do Itta! Betty takes Mary's money, waves her on and helps the next customer.
So no then? That's a no? Betty ignores her. Mary waits, loads the newspapers into bag.

Sometimes crosswords are even better than life. Here's how. They don't discriminate. Crosswords don't care if you're young or old; black or white; male, female or intersex. Crosswords only care if you're an idiot. And, really, that's okay, because if you have the IQ of a yam, finishing a crossword should be the least of your worries. Mary glances up at the TV news once more, then walks away

A half dozen NEWS CREWS rush to load and unload CNN news vans. JOURNALISTS, PHOTOGRAPHERS, PRODUCERS, SOUNDyT all in a mad rush to go get An unshaven and surprisingly calm STEVE balances camera equipment in one hand while he scratches a barely legible "Steve" onto a clipboard. A young PA takes the clipboard, hands Steve a bunch of gas masks. 9.
Steve heads to an open van where a disheveled, mid producer ANGUS MCCORMACK checks his watch.
Where the hell is he?
Probably doing his nails. -- paper 40ish reporter HARTMAN HUGHES rushes to the van on his fa napkin tucked in his shirt collar, bread crumbs
What do you mean "the big one"? Terrorists, natural disaster, what?
Pandemic. Hartman's eyes light up.
Half of the Midwest and spreading. Nobody's safe. Steve tries on a gas mask.
Please let it be the bird flu.
Bird flu is for pussies. This thing's unstoppable.
How's it spreading? Angus looks at Steve.
Squirrels. Hartman can barely contain his excitement.
Oh my God, they're everywhere!
Exactly.
Al Qaeda connection? 10.
Always a possibility.
Who wishes he was in Iraq now?
Not me!. Hartman grabs a gas mask and rushes to the van's side mir

I need blush. No, wait. I'll go pasty. It'll look like I could be the first media victim. "Hartman Hughes, no such thing as too close to the story". Hartman looks back at Steve and Angus. They're just stand there, unable to keep a straight face. Hartman deflates.
Assholes! I knew it was too good to be true. He throws his gas mask down, storms off.
Hartman, come on. Hartman gets in the elevator, hollers out to them.
I had a perfectly good bologna sandwich going on upstairs. Wasted! Angus and Steve watch the elevator door close, shrug it o
Next E-coli story breaks, he'll be fine.

An 1890 Colonial Revival home surrounded by White Oaks. Oversized statue of the Blessed Virgin in the flower bed. Mezuzah on the door. Face still in the newspaper, Mary trips up the steps and skids onto the porch. Her knee starts to bleed. 11.
Crap.

It's house that's been lived in. Every inch cluttered wit old newspapers, family photos, various objet d'art, and books, books and more books. Mary steps out of her boots and marches into the living r where her 50ish mother, MRS. HOROWITZ, sits reading with HOROWITZ (late 50's, professorial head to toe, furrowed b to worn loafers).
"Brilliant" is what they said. Never in the history of St. Margaret's Career Day have the children's brains been so inordinately stimulated as they were today by my presentation.
Good for you, sweetie. Mary pulls the newspapers out of her bag, sorts through t stacks them on top of the TV.
"Inspired", the teacher told me.
You get the Post? She hands him the paper.
"Engrossing" one child exclaimed.
A ten year old said that?
I'm sure that's what he meant. And "ebullient"-
What happened to your knee? Mary looks down at the blood dripping down from her knee her sock. She's completely annoyed - more at the question than the mess. 12.

Dad, some of the greatest orators of all time had their heads chopped off for their labors. I'm lucky to escape with a simple flesh wound. Mary hands over the last newspaper, heads out to the hall Her mother yells to her.
Change those socks before your date.
I told you I'm not going.
Mrs. Alchessi says you'll like this one.
Mrs. Alchessi has gliomatosis cerebri.
What?
A brain tumor characterized by, among other things, dementia. She's nuts. Mary walks up the stairs.
Mary, it's just a date. This is what normal girls your age do. Mary stops on the stairs.
I'm normal. Silence from her parents. Mary marches back into the livi room.
In fact, I'm normalis extremes. That's the kind of normal that doesn't get more normal.
Of course you are, sweetie. 13. Mary looks at her obviously lying mother and uncomfortabl father. Mary's mind reels, like her head is going to explode. Finally, a determination hits her.
I'll go. Mary bolts up the stairs to her room. Mr. and Mrs. Horowitz look at each other, surprised, happ
You ever want to see grandchildren, you better burn the damn boots. She swats him with her book, tries not to laugh.

Storage room or bedroom? Boxes and books all over the pla In the middle of it all, a bed. On the dresser, a bunch of photos of Mary Tyler Moore in 1970's. Taped to the mirror, the chosen photo Horowitz smart blue sweater and skirt ensemble. An wears the exact same outfit. Oddly, surprisingly current and actually hot. She leans over the gerbil cage next to her desk, taps to up the :Lone, fat occupant.

Carol, tonight I have a date. A blind one. Not the guy, I mean the situation. We are, as yet, unknown to one another... It's nerve wracking, I know. Try not to have a spontaneous epileptiform seizure. The doorbell rings. Mary freezes, listens for the muffled voices downstairs. She sits on the corner of her bed and breathes rapidly in paper bag. There's a knock on her bedroom door. Mary folds up the ba puts it in her pocket for later, then opens the door a cr It's her mother.
Guess who's here. 14.
I'd rather not. Mrs. Horowitz opens the door wider, takes a look at Mary, looks like she's going to cry.
Look at you.
i already did. Repeatedly.
You're beautiful.
Please don't mean on the inside.
Beautiful and smart. And fun. And interesting. Mary takes a deep breath, lets it out fast.
Let's hope all that does it for him.

A bored, CNN jacket wearing Steve looks up to see Mrs. Horowitz descending the stairs. Not far behind, Mary take each step like her knees are fused together but still man to look hot. Steve's pleasantly surprised. With one look at Steve, Mary's eyes glaze over as if a ch is screaming "hallelujah" in her brain. As Mary reaches the bottom step --
Mary, hi. I'm Steve. She puts up a finger - "just a second". She turns around and runs back upstairs. Steve looks at M Horowitz, confused.
And how's your mother? 15.
Great. Thanks. She just stares at him and smiles.
Mary runs into her room, kneels down in front of the mizr and crucifix on the wall. Hands clasped in prayer.

Gods. You may have noticed that I'm wearing clean socks. Translation: I'm really trying and thus should be amply rewarded. Thanks for your support. She gets up, has a second thought, gets back onto her kne
And by support I don't mean, you know - She hikes up her bra.
I mean your assistance, your furtherance, your advocacy of my efforts to get out there and... do what I'm supposed to do. She concentrates hard, opens her eyes. Now she's ready.
Steve waits as Mary walks down the stairs again, this tim bit more relaxed.
There we go. Mary makes it to the bottom of the stairs, steps into her boots. Her mother cringes. Steve's a bit surprised at the boots but who cares, Mary's still hot from the knee caps
Ready? Mary nods a bunch of times. 16.
Mrs. Horowitz. Goodnight. (calling into living room) Sir.
You kids have fun.
Be careful now. Don't forget your seatbelts. Mrs. Horowitz sees them out the door then heads into the living room. She waves to them out the window, trying to hide her worry but failing miserably.
She'll be fine. They look at each other - a bit of hope, a bit of dread.
Steve unlocks the driver's side door of his SUV while Mar waits at her door, nervous but smiling.
Sorry about this blind date thing. My mother -
I never went to kindergarten! He looks at her, totally confused.
They skipped me to the forth grade.
Okay. She gets in the car, fastens her seatbelt. Steve hesitate then heads to the driver's side, gets in.
I missed finger painting. He has no clue what to say.
Sorry? 17.
Me too. She lunges for his lips but the seatbelt snaps her back inches short.

Whoa! Undeterred by the whiplash, Mary undoes her seatbelt and tries again, this time making contact with Steve's lips. He's more than a little startled but kisses her back anyw all the while straining to see the Horowitz house.
Mary... uh, what about your mother? She straddles him and keeps kissing.
You're not her type. And she's married.
No, we're right in front of your house and... She undoes her sweater.
And I have no problem with that whatsoever. She kisses his neck. He looks up with a "thank you, God".
Steve?
Mary.
Is it Steven with a V or Stephen with a P-H?
She works over his face over like it's an ice cream cone. 18.

I thought so. There are almost a million Stevens with a V in the country, you know. It's much more popular than the P-H way, almost twice as popular in fact. I think it's the Brits who prefer the P-H. They love their P-H's over there. Not as much as they love their fish and chips but still, they love them. It was the media thing, you know, that's why our moms wanted us to get together. You work in the media, so do I. We really have to hand it to our moms, Steve, we do, and not just for raising us, or for thriving during a time when women painstakingly struggled for equality, but I mean we should hand it to them for being visionaries and predicting our all encompassing compatibility. We're professionally compatible, yes, but it's occurring to me at this particular moment that we're also sexually compatible, and I don't know if you noticed like I noticed but we're also both wearing blue. What are the chances of that? Actually, if I really think about it, the chances are probably pretty good. Blue is one of the most popular three colors, however, yours is- She leans forward and checks the fabric tag on the neck o his jacket. She can't quite read it. She reaches up and flips on the interior light. Steve's just about blinded. She grabs the tag, reads.
Nylon. And mine... She grabs her own tag and reads it, just about elbowing S in the eye.
Polyester! See? Both synthetic fibres! And the chances of that are much smaller than the chances of us just wearing blue. Steve looks at Mary - suddenly fully aware of her crazine 19.
Do you like crosswords?
Sure. She just about jumps out of her pants with excitement.
Me too! And semantics, the study of the meaning of words? You love words, right?
What's not to love.
I know! She can hardly believe her good fortune. Her mind reels j as fast as her lips.

Steve with a V, you know what we are? We're didymous. Two of a kind. Two rare earth elements brought together by Norns, that's Scandinavian for The Destinies. You want to make out for ten to fifteen minutes more then go get a six pack of Twinkies and Mountain Dew and stay up all night and talk? Steve is frozen. No escape - then it hits him. He jumps a bit, pulls out his cell phone.
Sorry. I have to get this.
I didn't hear it ring.
Vibrate.
I didn't feel it
You didn't? (into phone) This is Steve... What? Really? Now? If I don't have a choice... 20. He hangs up, looks at Mary like he feels bad.
Work. I have to go to... Boston. This happens all the time. You know how it is. Wherever news happens... Mary gets off of him, slides back into her seat, buttons sweater.
It's okay. When you get back we can have plenty of quality time.
Sure. I'll call you. He leans over, opens her door.
Steve, this has been a night to remember.
No kidding. You certainly are - He searches for any word that will do. Mary jumps in.
Normal.
You read my mind. Never happier, she jumps out of the car. As he drives away, she pulls the paper bag out of her poc breathes into it.
Mary's parents hear the door open then Mary's footsteps h the stairs. Mrs. Horowitz jumps up, rushes to meet her.
Sweetie, what's wrong? What happened? My God, you've barely been gone ten minutes. Mary stops on the stairs, turns back. 21.
Mom, sometimes that's all you need to know he's the one! Mary smiles big, takes the rest of the stairs up two at a time. Mrs. Horowitz is about to follow her.
That girl makes up her mind the moon is green, it's green. Leave her be. It'll pass. Eventually. Mrs. Horowitz moves away from the stairs, no less worried
Mary leaps from the doorway and lands on her bed in penci pose, smiling up at the ceiling.
Eleven letter word for serendipity. She screams into her pillow.
The perfect answer: S-E-R-E-N-D-I-P- I-T-Y. Serendipity. Why would you ever need a better word than that? She sits up, grabs her notebook, starts to draw out a new crossword puzzle.

A busy newspaper office. COURIERS make deliveries, JOURNALISTS talk at their desks, SECRETARIES count the minutes until they can go home. In the Editor's office, JIM SOLOMAN looks over the newspa layout with an ASSISTANT.
Let's split the gardening feature into two weeks. Keep them in suspense. He steps back, looks at the whole layout.
Looks good. How are we doing here? 22. He checks his watch.
Five minutes to spare. Look at that. The Assistant points to a blank corner of page 26. Soloma surprised, and not particularly impressed.
Horowitz.
Mary stands at the front of the full elevator, smiling, a piece of paper gripped in her hand.

When I was a fledgling (that means novice) crossword constructor, I would find comfort in the words of the learned crossword sages. Above all, my hero is Manny Nosowsky, frequent New York Times contributor and all around cruciverbial master.
Mary walks out of the elevator and heads through the offi Nobody seems to notice her.
Manny says that a crossword puzzle's greatness can be determined by asking three simple questions. She marches in the direction of the Editor's office.
Is it solvable? She almost collides with a mail cart but keeps walking.
Is it entertaining? She arrives at the Editor's office, plants her feet in th doorway. 23.
Does it s arkle? She looks down at the crossword puzzle in her hands, smil holds it out for Soloman. Soloman grabs the crossword and hands it right to the Assistant, who rushes it out the door.
Two OLD LADIES sit under the hair dryers, each doing the Atlanta Citizen crossword puzzle. They're stumped. The first Old Lady hollers over the noise of the dryer.

head_text.subj: I CAN'T GET ANY OF THESE

text: The other Old Lady holds up her blank crossword, shrugs.
The TAXI DRIVER sits in the parked taxi doing the crosswo
This is bullshit.
A long haired GUY gets up from his seat, puts his coat on male EXECUTIVE sits down and spots the newspaper opened t the crossword puzzle.
Don't even bother, man. I don't know what the deal is, but it looks like all the answers are --
Soloman holds up the crossword page.
Steve? Mary sits and smiles. 24.
Every single answer is "Steve"? Who the hell is Steve anyway? No wait, I don't care, but I do care that you pissed off our readers. Mary's smile falls a bit.
I thought you knew better than to pull something like this. It's unprofessional, it's -- to him. He's too frustrated, the words aren't coming
Romantic?
No!
Creativo? That's Italian for "creative".
No.
How about -
Mary. We're letting you go.
Oh. up her Kroger She looks like she's going to cry. She picks bag, fidgets.
Maybe I could make it up to you by doing a fishing themed crossword. I know how you love the piscatology. Soloman shakes his head -- it's done. Mary hesitates then finally gets up.
Okay. I'll just give you some time then. We'll talk next week. 25. He ignores that. She walks out, seemingly content, a bit denial. A PAYROLL CLERK sees the elevator doors close behind Mary
She forgot her severance.
Don't you mean "Steverance"? They both laugh.
Mary walks up to the front steps where Mr. Horowitz sits
waiting for her. She sits down beside him. He holds up Atlanta Citizen crossword.
Interesting way to go.
Indeed.
They like it? She points to the other newspaper in his lap.
Finished with the Times? She goes to take the paper. He stops her.
Neshama, the puzzle. How'd it go? She looks around. Nowhere to run.
How do you think? She looks at him -- worry all over his face. She hesitate for a moment then sucks it up.
Because if you're thinking that they loved it, that they thought it was imaginative and bold and evocative... you would be right. 26. He's not sure how to take that.
And Steve?
He works a lot, you know. Travels all the time. 'Tis possible he has not yet espied it. She picks up the crossword, admires it.

But when he does, I'm sure he'll say, "that Mary Horowitz... is a catch. Where oh where has she been all my empty life? From here onward my life will be divided into 'before I met Mary' and 'after I met Mary' with the second part being far superior. I am lonely no more. The missing letter in my puzzle has at last been found."
I don't want you getting your hopes up too much.
I'm not.
An exec office. Steve relaxes on the sofa next to Angus while Hartman noses around the office.
We're going to hit rush. We'll have to take the second flight. Exec. Producer DAN CORBITT walks in, heads straight for h desk.
You're set. KDFW's on site now. Angus and Steve start to get up.
Hang on. They sit. Corbitt grabs the remote control, turns the TV 27.

Anybody want to tell me about this? He fast forwards through footage of Hartman reporting fro greenhouse. Corbitt slows it to normal speed, mutes it. They watch as Hartman interviews an attractive female BOTANIST holding a test tube with a seedling in it. Hartm keeps pointing to the seedling - which happens to be righ front of the Botanist's generous breasts. The camera gets closer and closer - each time it pulls aw Hartman points to the seedling again to force the camera close - basically turning the piece into a giant boob-fes
Take a look at those... plants. Corbitt pauses it on the worst shot, looks at Steve.
We can't use this. Hartman fakes disgust.
Of course not. Nice camera work, Stevie. Steve glares at Hartman. Corbitt points at the frozen sho on the TV screen, looks at Steve.
You want to go back to the Weather Channel, try that again. Corbitt checks his watch, points them out the door.
Get out of here. Don't embarrass me in Dallas. Hartman, Angus and Steve walk out. Steve nods to Hartman thanks asshole. In the hallway, Steve's cell phone rings. He answers it.
What?... Mom, let me call you back. 28. He listens, signals to Angus he needs a minute, then stop a reception area. He sorts through the newspapers, pulls the Atlanta Citizen, flips through it.
What page? He finds Mary's crossword. He looks at it closely, totall confused. It takes him more than a second to get it. He laughs -- then suddenly reality sets in.
Jesus.

Mary does a crossword while soaking in the bathtub. Witho missing an answer, she reaches over the side of the tub, grabs the telephone on the floor. She checks the dial ton hangs up quickly, continues with the puzzle.
Four letter word for am I going to wait my whole life for Steve to call? She suddenly stops writing.
Nope. She flails out of the tub like a salmon heading upstream, grabs a towel barely big enough to cover her. Without any effort to dry off, she runs out of the bathroom.

Towel wrapped around her but barely covering, Mary reache the top of the stairs. Her wet feet sliding all over the place, she opts for the safety of a banister slide. She g up on it, slides a few inches before realizing what a bad idea it was.
Ow ow ouch. She gets off the banister, slops the rest of the way down stairs, jumps into the doorway of the living room. 29.

The news is Steve's life! It's not just what he does, it's who he is, imbedded deep down in his polymer of nucleotides. I should be out there by his side. That's what girlfriends do, isn't it? Let him concentrate on his work. I'll concentrate on the relationship. It won't be easy, I know, but neither is quantum physics or... the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle or... paper mache, but I've managed to do fine with those, haven't I? She looks at her parents. They sit at a table playing bri with MR. and MRS. HANCOCK.
Mary, you remember the Hancocks.
Top of the evening. Mr. Hancock checks out Mary's bare legs as she stands in puddle of bath water. Mrs. Hancock lifts her husband's ch snaps him out of it.
Loved this week's puzzle, dear. Whoever Steve is, he must be a very lucky young man. Mr. Horowitz gives Mrs. Hancock a look - "don't encourage her".
Exactly! And all I have to do is go to him, be near him, and do my best to radiate... me. Mr. Horowitz doesn't like the sound of this.
And where exactly will this radiation take place? Mary rushes to the TV, turns it on, flips it to CNN.
A shot of the Medieval Times castle in Dallas, TX. The banner on the screen reads "WORKPLACE KILLING".
Wherever news happens, Dad. Wherever news happens.

PASSENGERS board the bus destined for Dallas. Way too excited in her red boots, Mary is the last in line. She h her mother then jumps up onto the first step of the bus. Horowitz holds Mary's knapsack and Kroger bag, shakes his head in disbelief.
This is nuts. Mary takes the bags from him.
Abe, Catherine, I'm off. I don't know where I'm going - The Greyhound Bus DRIVER hollers from behind her.
Dallas.
Geographically yes, I know. Figuratively, philosophically, spiritually, much less so. My entire life is before me. The world is my ostrea edulis... That means the edible kind of oyster.
That's beautiful, sweetie. You sure you won't take mine instead? She tries to switch her leather bag for Mary's Kroger bag Mary resists, points back and forth between the two bags.
Mom, two handles, two handles, they both hold stuff, what's the difference? Mrs. Horowitz goes to explain, gives up. 31.
That Steve shows any disrespect, you're on the next bus back here.

Disrespect. Do you mean unmannerly, tactless, vulgar? Because he's a straight man, Dad, and some things can't be helped. But if you mean inconsiderate to me, contemptuous toward me, insulting, irreverent, uncivil -
Let's go already! She steps up one more step, yells out to her parents and
I don't know when I'll be back but I do know this- The door shuts in her face.
Mary waves to her worried parents through the closed door
(to herself) I'm not coming back alone.
Local and national NEWS CREWS are camped across the road the Medieval Times castle. Among them, Steve holds the CN camera on Hartman. A young audio tech JOSH hovers nearby.

Paula, what started out as a routine rehearsal here at the Dallas Medieval Times turned deadly when an employee allegedly turned on his fellow performers. Twenty- four hours later, at least thirty employees are still being held hostage by the assailant, their lives hanging in the balance. He listens to his earpiece, nods. 32.

The castle you see behind me is one of eight medieval Times dinner theatre restaurants. Guests who cross the drawbridge enjoy a medieval style feast while watching the main attraction: knights engaging in a battle of strength and skill. The restaurant promises "fun, feasting and fighting" but it appears that this time, fun was in short supply. Who doesn't?
jMuerte! iMuerte! iMuerte!
I have to go find Steve. How do I look? Unwashed hair, bed head, and there's a chunk of a Twinkie caked onto Mary's ear. Elizabeth picks the Twinkie off, smooths down Mary's hair.
Perfect.
I'll be back. Save me a sign! And if Cloris comes out, tell her I loved her in "My Little Pony: The Movie". Mary runs off as Howard and Elizabeth join the crowd of f
Mary walks among the news vans. At the entrance to a near tent, Hartman spots her, waves her over.
Hi gorgeous. What'd you do to your hair? 64.
Slept on it in the car. Where's Steve? Is he okay?
Never better. Come in and wait. He'll be back soon.

A briefing area is set up - folding chairs, table, podium bunch of male journalists sit around the table playing po Vince (CNN), DOUG (CNN), the COURT TV REPORTER, a BBC NEW PHOTOGRAPHER, a FRENCH PHOTOGRAPHER, A SPANISH JOURNALIST Angus. Hartman escorts Mary in. The guys perk up a bit.
You all know Mary? Steve's girlfriend? Mary shakes hands around the table, greets them all in th native tongues.
Hello... Bonjour... Hola... Jolly afternoon... She gets to Angus. He kisses her hand.
My dear, sit. He shoves the BBC guy out of the way to make room for Mar next to him. Vince shuffles the cards.
Mary, you in?
Poker? Technically I'm familiar but I've never actually played. With people, I mean.
She's in. Doug throws in some cash as Vince starts to deal. 65.

Howard wanders through the crowd wearing an "I V Cloris" shirt over his own. He passes a VENDOR selling "Innocence Beads", "Acquittal Incense" and "autographed" Cloris Leac photos. The crowd continues to grow. A Candles are lit, healing rituals performed, donuts passed around.
Mary holds her cards close to her.
"There are few things that are so unpardonably neglected in our country as poker." Guess who said that one. She looks around the table. The guys, except Angus, are starting to lose their patience.
Mark Twain. And you know what else-
Darling, you in or not?
Sorry. Mary looks at her cards, thinks about it for way too long then grabs a handful of coins from her Kroger bag, slaps on the table.
Send it, ladies! Steve steps into the tent, spots Mary, turns to run back
Don't go, Steve! Look who's here. Mary jumps up - just about knocks the table over, then sustains a number of injuries trying to leap over chairs. last she makes it to Steve, hugs him.
Thank God you're okay! 66. He looks over her shoulder and mouths "you're dead" to Hartman.
He holds her back at arm's length, looks at her, goes speak then stops himself, pulls her outside the tent.
Steve tries to stay calm talking to Mary.
You have to stop stalking me.
I'm not. It's more like picking travel destinations based on where you happen to be working.
Stalking.
Hartman told me you wanted me here. Now that I am, what better opportunity for us to get to know each other better.
This is crazy.
Hartman said you'd say that.
Go home, Mary.
And he said you'd say that too. It's just your fear talking. Steve just about loses it.
He's not my friend, he's not your friend. He's just an asshole who thinks it's fun to string you along and make my life hell. He yells toward the tent.
Hughes! Get out here! 67. Mary looks right at him.

You know how sometimes you see a pinguid (that means fat and greasy) guy with an attractive girl and you think how the heck did he pull that off? People won't think that when they look at us. We're perfectly matched. She can hardly contain her excitement.
Hartman peeks out of the tent.
For the hundredth time, Steve, no, I am not interested in a threesome with you and your new girlfriend. Steve points to Mary.
Tell her the truth. About all the crap you told her.
Okay. Fine. Hartman goes to Mary, grabs her hand.

Everything I said about Steve, about his feelings for you, his hopes, his dreams, his fears, his unexplainable odor, forget about it. Forget everything I said. None of it was true. Mary's stunned, devastated. She looks like she's going to cry. Hartman and Steve look at each other - what now? Hartman shoves him forward. Steve reluctantly puts a comforting hand on her shoulder.
Because nothing I said comes close to the enormity of Steve's real feelings for you! 68. Mary perks up. Steve yanks his hand off her shoulder like it's on fire.
It's a love that defies words! Steve jumps him. Hartman fights back. Mary's horrified.

Stop it, you guys! Stop! "Victory attained by violence is tantamount to a defeat, for it is momentary." You know who said that? Gandhi. And me. Just now. The fight continues. Mary half covers her eyes.
At the poker table, the guys hear scuffling outside.
Fight! They all jump up and run out of the tent.
Steve gets a few jabs to Hartman as the rest of the guys calmly watch.
Nice one.
Somebody's going to be crying in a minute. Angus hugs Mary to "console" her. Hartman gets Steve in a headlock. Mary can't even watch.
I'm going to go with Hughes on this one.
Come on, the guy wears makeup. The guys all start pulling out cash to place bets. Mary spots the cash changing hands. 69.

No! This isn't about money! It's about courage, love, honor and all things virtuous and pure. Steve, kick him in the leberknoedel! Hartman looks up at her, hurt. The distraction costs him. Steve knees him then follows with a jab to his face.
Ohhhh! Hartman drops to his knees, tries to pull himself togethe
Tell her!
Okay, alright. Hartman wipes his lip, looks up at Mary.

Mary, millions of people believe what I tell them every night. Why shouldn't you? Steve dives at him. Hartman swings and gets him right in nose. One of their cell phones ring, then another, then a the guys' phones go off.
Verdict's in. They all rush off to the court house, leaving a stunned M standing alone.
He fought for me. Happiest moment of her life.
The crowd cheers as CLORIS LEACHMAN is whisked out of the court house and into a police car. She waves to her fans she goes. The Court TV Reporter is on camera. 70.

The end to a difficult and often emotional trial, the verdict finally in, Cloris Leachman found not guilty of the murder of her twenty-six year old lover Juan Carlos Velasquez. Down the row of journalists, the BBC CREW.
After a devastating eight months, Leachman at last vindicated despite overwhelming evidence against her. Six more cameras down, the French Reporter.

Eyewitness testimony, fingerprints on every inch of the body, the murder weapon still warm in her Chanel handbag - And finally at the end of the line, Hartman - his hair a mess, his lip cut, his mood sour. A few feet away filming, Steve's nose bleeds down his chi and shirt.
And as she left the court room today a free woman, the cheers of her devoted fans carrying her forward -

head_text.subj: OH MY GOD, STEVE, YOU'RE BLEEDING

text: The camera is knocked out of position as Mary rushes Stev Angus steps in and pulls her away. A COP grabs her. Mary looks back to Steve as she's dragged back to the fan area.
Please! Somebody help him! Apply a vasoconstrictor, a nasal tampon, anything! At the absolute least, direct pressure and a clean tissue! Steve puts the camera back in place. Hartman recovers fas 71.

As you can see, Cloris Leachman's fans have become surprisingly violent despite her victory here today. Add this to the list of the most dangerous locations for journalists. Iraq, Somalia, Lebanon, Sri Lanka... and just about any place Cloris Leachman fans gather. Hartman wipes blood from his lip.
Hartman Hughes putting his life at risk to report live from Santa Fe, New Mexico. They cut. Hartman grabs a hand mirror, points to his face yells out to Steve.
This is my gift, understand, my instrument. Makes no difference if you're walking around looking like Quasimodo. Ignoring Hartman, Steve walks over to Angus.
How long do you figure until - Steve's phone rings. He cringes, answers it.
A furious Corbitt holds the phone and replays the live sh of Hartman at the court house.
Who the hell was that?
Steve hesitates on the phone. 72.

This girl. She's been following me... She's not my girlfriend... He listens, clenches his teeth, hands the phone to Angus. Angus listens, Steve grabs his equipment, waits in dread. Angus hangs up the phone, hands it back to Steve.
I'm done?
Consider yourself temporarily saved by the storm. It's worse than they thought. We've got to move. Steve grabs his equipment. They start walking.
He'll probably fire you after.
Any luck, the storm will kill me first.
Elizabeth runs around hugging other fans as Mary stands a the fence watching the press wrap up, worried. Clyde the Shaman joins her at the fence, looks right at h raises a finger to his lips.
Shhhh.
What? I didn't -
Shhhh. He puts his hands on the sides of her head. Mary's confus and a bit freaked out.
In here. So loud. Always thinking, thinking, thinking. Mary goes to speak, stops herself. Clyde keeps his hands still on her head, looks into her eyes. 73.

You already found what you're looking for. Mary's eyes soften and she's suddenly calm. A moment of peace. Suddenly, Mary spots Hartman, Steve and Angus rush past. breaks away from Clyde, rushes along the fence to catch u
Wait! Steve! Hartman spots her.
Sorry, darling, we're on to the next story.
No, wait! Attendee! She runs to the end of the fence, jumps it, runs after th
Mary runs to catch up with Steve, Angus and Hartman as th rush to the trucks.
Angus and Hartman load up the truck as Steve turns back t Mary, seething.
Considering you probably just cost me my job, maybe you don't want to talk to me right now.
But I do! If you're in trouble because of me I can fix it, I can explain to your boss. He or she probably just doesn't understand our relationship.
We don't have a relationship. 74.
Sure we do, it's just in the pupa stage right now.
Mary, go home! She looks at him, hurt.
Go home. He jumps in the CNN truck as Angus starts it up. Mary loo around, helpless.

Mary runs to the street behind the CNN truck, stops on th sidewalk. Behind her, a run down rep theater -- "All Abov Eve" on the marquee. As she watches the truck drive away, her panic suddenly t to resolve.

Six letter word for "over my lifeless, rigormortic and maggot infested, i.e. dead, body am I giving up now"... D-O-G-G- motherfucking-E-D. Dogged. She gets out her Chapstick, liberally applies it, dabs a on her temples as well.

Normally I don't condone swearing. I think it's something people do when they don't have the vocabulary to express themselves properly, but even I, with my plenitudinous vocab, must admit -- every once in a while, it's okay to get a bit peppery -
Mary talks on a pay phone. No pacing, no fidgeting. She means business. 75.
I got him in trouble, Dad. I have to go find him and make it right. There's three places they could be headed. She pulls a note pad out of her pocket, looks it over.

For each story, I've worked out an equation of potential human casualties, estimated property damage, availability of endlessly repeatable images, with bonus points for anything involving reporters in galoshes. There's no doubt in my mind. They're heading to the storm in Galveston.
Mr. Horowitz talks on the living room phone, his wife on hallway phone - they look at each other in exasperation.
Enough is enough. You've got to get home, turn in your crossword for next week -
I can't think of work at a time like this!
You can't chase that boy any more. If he doesn't appreciate you it's ridiculous to -
Mary screams into the phone.
Ridiculous? Mom! How many times did you propose to dad?
Mr. and Mrs. Horowitz think about it for a second. 76.
Twice. Seven times.
Mary yells on the phone. PASSENGERS start to stare.

I rest my case! If you gave up the first time dad said no then I wouldn't exist. Telling me to give up so soon on my potential husband- to-be, birth father of my twelve future children and adoptive father of my gerbil Carol -- you might as well be saying that you wish you had given up too and that you never married dad and that I'd never been born. Is that what you're saying?
Mrs. Horowitz looks at her husband.
Give Steve my best.
Be careful.
And eat! A biscuit, anything. A V8 wouldn't kill you.
Elizabeth stands at the bus to Oklahoma City, a pile of Leachman signs at her feet. Mary approaches.
Sure you don't want to come along?
I wish, but I only left enough cat food out for two days. I'll miss you guys! Elizabeth hugs them both, jumps on the bus. Howard and Ma watch as she struggles to her seat with all the signs. 77.
Howard and Mary fasten their seat belts.
This storm could be bad. Sure you want to drive into it?
How bad could it be?
The CNN METEOROLOGIST points at the map, images swirling around the Gulf Coast.

Hurricane Lorraine, currently rated category four, expected to hit landfall by tomorrow evening. Making the situation even more frightening, that area of Texas currently in the midst of its worst tornado season in history. Tornado images appear on the map.
And here's where it gets interesting. A black swarm graphic appears as well.
Add the looming cicada migration to the mix and no one knows just how devastating this storm could be.
A WEATHER CHANNEL METEOROLOGIST talks on camera, complete calm.
Category four hurricane, an F-3 or "severe" tornado, billions upon billions of cicadas -- collectively now being termed a "category fifteen winged tornadocane". 78.
The Hispanic KTFT METEOROLOGIST points to the green scree
Tornadocane.
The KPRC ANCHOR is on camera.
Tornadocane.
The KLUJ METEOROLOGIST looks at his notes, tries to keep together, half talks to himself.
God really hates us now.
Torrential rain pelts the line of vehicles heading north. The only movement in the southbound lanes -- Howard's car

In full rain gear, Hartman walks past rows of boarded up businesses. Steve follows him with the camera. Angus, Dou and Josh are close behind. The rain is deafening, the wind ridiculous. It's all Hart can do to stay on his feet.

(yelling his head off) And this time, the warnings were hard to ignore. One Galvestonian told us "tornados, we can handle. Hurricanes we can handle. Bugs we can handle. Put 'em all together and that's a storm I don't need to see". A wise man indeed. Something off to the side catches Hartman's eye -- it's a picnic table blowing down the street. 79.
Oooh! Get that! Steve gets the shot then pretends to make adjustments to camera while he discretely scans the area, on the lookout Mary.

location: HOWARD'S CAR ON 1-45 TO GALVESTON TX

text: Howard and Mary can barely see out the window. The car inches along. Mary digs in a KFC bag, takes out a handy wipe, starts cleaning her body with it.

And when I met Steve, I knew right away we had a lot in common. We're both in the media, we both love crosswords, we both love words. We both felt this unexplainable connection, no matter how much his instinct might be to fight it. That's okay. We just have to get to know each other better, that's all. She uses the wipe on her face, gets a bit on her lip and taste is awful. She rolls down the window, closes her eye and gently sticks her face out to rinse with rain water. The car hits a flooded patch of the road. A wave of mud washes up and smacks Mary right in the face.
Crap. She starts the handy wipe bath all over again. A nervous Howard speaks up.
I saw Steve talking to you... He wasn't very nice. Mary makes herself busy putting the handy wipe in her Kro bag then looks out the window.
If there's one thing I learned from crossword puzzles it's that you can't give up.

MARY (cont'd) Sometimes you run into a doozy and you think you'll never be able to solve it in a million years. If you quit, you're right, but if you stick with it, you'll figure it out. Eventually. She looks at Howard.
I have to give it one more try. I have to fix the mess I made with his work, then maybe he and I -- For the first time, she doesn't seem so sure. Howard notices.
You know what my favorite part of doing crosswords is? When you know something you didn't think you knew. Mary thinks about it, then turns back to looking out the window.
Me too.
Hartman stands in the middle of a pier that looks moments away from being carried out to sea. Steve shoots from a s on the pier a few feet closer to shore but not much safer
Paula, this pier was closed to the public twenty-four hours ago, and for good reason. Steve inches a bit closer for the shot, his footing unsta Josh moves in and hangs on to Steve to keep him steady.

As I stand here, I can actually feel the structure moving under my feet. The only thing between me and the limitless depths of the sea is this two-by-four railing that - The railing flies off. Hartman drops to his knees and cra to the other railing then hangs on for dear life. Steve a Josh struggle to hang on to the camera and each other. 81. Steve signals,to Hartman to wrap it up fast. Hartman talk slower than ever.

And Paula I have to tell you, not only has my hearing been permanently damaged by the sheer force of the rain hitting my eardrums, but at this point, I'm beginning to wonder if I'll even make it out alive. He raises his head up for the big finish, gets hammered b the wind and rain.
This is Hartman Hughes, reporting live from Galveston, Texas. Steve and Josh start backing up off the pier with Hartman crawling behind them. Steve yells back to him.
You had to get the pier shot. Had to. Just about got us all killed. Happy? Hartman points in the water, yells.
Steve jumps, looks to where Hartman is pointing -- it's a plastic bag floating by in the water.
You're such an asshole. Steve walks off the pier mad as hell.
Come on, that was funny. You have to admit... Stevie?

location: HOWARD'S CAR ON 1-45 TO GALVESTON TX

text: The northbound lanes now empty, Howard's car is the only on the road. 82.
Howard stares out the window, the first look of real fear his face.
Hang on. He hits the brakes, starts backing up as quickly as possi Mary looks ahead -- sees what looks like a tornado up ahe
Oh my God. Howard backs under an overpass, points to a protected are the cement embankment.
Mary and Howard run up the cement embankment as the rain winds swirl all around them.

We'll just have to wait for this to pass, then we'll keep going. It'll be okay. They look down to the road just in time to see Howard's c picked up and blown right through the underpass, landing its side in a ditch fifty yards away.
Crap!
Mr. and Mrs. Horowitz watch images of the storm on TV, th captions read "BREAKING NEWS: KILLER STORM". Mrs. Horowit crosses herself. Mr. Horowitz puts an arm around her.
She's fine. She's fine.
This is all your fault.
I know. 83.
Steve is asleep sitting upright in the back of the rental van. A hand caresses his cheek.
Steve... Oh Steve... Steve awakens in panic.

head_text.subj: GO AWAY, GO AWAY, GO AWAY

text: 13 Steve looks at the person in front of him -- it's a scare year old MEXICAN BOY.
Who the hell are you? What are you doing?
They pay me twenty dollar to wake you. Steve looks outside the van, sees Doug and Hartman laughi hard. The Kid scurries out of the van. Angus gets in, ope up his laptop.
You seen her?
She's too smart to come here during this. Steve looks around like he's crazy.
No, she's here somewhere. I can feel it.
As the storm calms around them, Howard and an exhausted M crouch in the sheltered area. They use a little flashligh on Mary's keychain to watch debris blowing by.
I spy with my little eye a chemical element from group two of the periodic table. 84. Howard points to a discarded fireworks casing at their fe
Barium... I spy with my little
eye... a transition metal She barely has the energy to get the word out.

Cobalt. Mary points to a steel belted tire on the ground, lays ba and shuts her eyes. Howard takes something out of his - i pocket, puts it in her hand. Mary looks at it shrivelled, sculpted apple head. She smiles, hardly able keep her eyes open.
Mother Teresa.
My best seller. I'm an apple sculptor. She's quiet for once. Howard watches her drift off.

I went to school for physics but got bored. Now I just make these and sell them on appleheadsrule.com. I was going to give that one to my girlfriend in Bangor but I can make her another one. She'd probably prefer a Stephen Hawking one anyway. Science is her life. Not like my girlfriend in Tacoma. She's really into Jesus. Same as my other girlfriend in Duluth. He waits for a response - nothing.
Maybe I'll meet them in person one day. They're just so far away and I don't get out much, not farther than the apple orchard or the post office anyway.
But you're out now. He's a bit surprised she was listening. 85.

I saw the people on TV fighting for Baby Peggy. It wasn't far from my house, and the people there looked nice enough, so I went. I thought I had everything I needed at home but then I thought, maybe there's more.
Maybe there is.
Can I tell you something? Mary nods.
I like your eyeballs.
They're fuscous, that means -
Brownish gray. I know. They both smile.
Downed trees, flooded lawns, debris all over the place bu all in all, not too bad.
The storm subsided, nothing but a light rain. Howard and Mary stand beside the car on its side in the shallow ditc
You know what I'd call this?
Quagmire?
Imbroglio, Howard. That means we're screwed. 86.
Dan Corbitt talks to another EXEC. at the water cooler.
Storm's over. What else is happening? The Exec shrugs and yawns.
A BUSINESSMAN picks up a newspaper, looks at the front pa it's a photo from the Westminster Garden Show.
Sloooowww news day.
A couple of bored REPORTERS sit tapping pens on their des
Fire, a car chase, anything?
There is nothing going on, man. Nada.

15 DEAF KIDS bounce up a small hill, followed by three fe TEACHERS. When they finally reach the top, they all st op Ahead of them, down the hill, the Tri-Parish Fair - compl with carnival rides, pie contests, music, dancing, rodeo livestock shows.

(speaking while signing to the kids) Who's ready for some fun? The deaf kids start running down the hill, straight for t petting zoo. 87. Just when they're close enough to smell the goats, tgroun gives way from the back and the kids drop out of sight front of the Teachers - each kid taken tota off having heard the dropping behind them. A g lly i ant puf dust settles to reveal a gaping hole in the earth. The Teachers drop their picnic baskets and scream their h off.
A messy living room, the TV on, nobody watching it. ON THE TV: "BREAKING NEWS - ABANDONED MINE DISASTER".
An abandoned mine shaft on the outskirts of Eunice, Louisiana. The children, apparently all hearing impaired, enjoying a trip' to the county fair, blissfully unaware of the danger that lay ahead.
The FOX NEWS ANCHOR is on camera.
No word yet on injuries. No word on when, or if, rescuers will be able to reach the special needs children. Well continue to bring you news as this tragic story unfolds.
As Mary and Howard try to tip the car, Mary is distracted a rental van barrelling down the interstate, northbound.
Steve drives, Hartman is next to him. Angus is in the bac with Doug and Josh. 88.
Tornadocane my ass. Where the hell were the cicadas? Retards in a mine shaft, now that's a story.
They're deaf, asshole. They spot Mary and Howard up ahead in the ditch, next to car on its side.
Look, it's your girlfriend.
We're not stopping. Hartman grabs a piece of paper, writes fast.
We can't just leave them.
Highway patrol's down here every hour. It's not like they'll rot in the ditch. As they get closer, Hartman rolls down his window, folds the piece of paper.
What the hell are you doing?
Getting some fresh air. It helps my pores. Steve tries to grab the paper.
Hughes!
Yes, Steven?
You're not telling her where we're going.
Aren't I? 89. Hartman leans out the window with the paper, waves it aro Steve reaches for it, one hand on the wheel. As he grabs Hartman, the truck starts swerving.
Christ, you two. You'll get us killed. Angus leans into the front seat, tries to steady the stee wheel.
Mary spots the rental van approaching, swerving - Hartman waving a piece of paper out the window. As the van passes by, Hartman lets the paper go.
Hartman rolls up the window, happy with himself. Steve sl him in the arm.
Asshole! Hartman laughs, rubs his arm in pain.
Mary rushes to the ditch, picks up the paper.
"Eunice, Louisiana. Please..." She stops reading, looks a bit uneasy. Howard steps forwa grabs the note.
"Please meet..." He looks at Mary, disgusted, continues reading.
M-E-A-T. "Please meat me there. XO Steve".
See? He needs me, if only to help with his spelling. 90.
No kidding. She rushes to the car, Howard joins her. They push the ca with everything they have, it tips back onto its wheels. jump in the car and start it up.

SECURITY PERSONNEL guard the closed entrance and turn awa pissed off FAIR PATRONS. At the edge of the fair grounds, the ferris wheel casts a shadow over the rescue site. The whole area has been overtaken by RESCUERS and their equipment. POLICE guard t tape to keep ONLOOKERS back. Local MEDIA circulates. Hartman kneels at the back of the ambulance, holding the of one of the Teachers. Steve gets it on camera, all the while looking around, a bit paranoid.
And what went through your mind when you realized they were gone? The Teacher just bawls. Hartman turns to the camera.

Grief too strong for words. That's the best way to describe this tragic, tragic scene. One minute, a merry day at the fair. The next minute, helpless babes savagely sucked into the menacing abyss. The Teacher bawls even harder. Hartman gives her a "there there" then continues talking to camera.

And here's how hopeless the rescue looks at this moment. The earth surrounding hole is far too perilous for anybody to approach on foot. Moving heavy rescue equipment in too close could mean death for the rescuers as well. Its cold down there, wet, dark, probably a few snakes and rats moving around.

HARTMAN (cont'd) If the hearing impaired children even survived the fall, they're undoubtedly dealing with serious injuries, although some may have had their fall cushioned by their deaf brothers and sisters who dropped before them. Nevertheless, they've got to be in complete misery. Even if one them is telling the next "it'll be okay", it's not like he, or she, can hear a word of it.
The coal dust covered kids sit in the dark, totally unhar A few of them play rock, paper, scissors. Others braid ea other's hair. An 8 year old boy signs to his friend.
I don't know what the hell happened but I smell a lawsuit.

Behind the taped off area, a crowd is forming. A school b pulls up and drops off a bunch more people. They place th stuffed animals, notes, flowers at the tape barrier. A bu of them start crying. Among them, some familiar faces fro the Oklahoma protestors.

Rescuers keep a safe distance from the perilous hole. A RESCUE SUPERVISOR oversees the effort, watches as a bucke attached to the old crane, barely big enough for one pers A FIREMAN gets in the bucket, doesn't fit. He gets out. A SKINNY FIREMAN is pushed forward. He gets in. The bucket is lowered into the ground. Hartman jumps in front of the scene. Steve follows with the camera.
To some, a simple crane. To the trapped, innocent, special children -- the answer to their prayers. The cable lowering the bucket jerks and stops. The crowd gasps. Hartman stays on camera. 92.
Or is it? The cable jerks and begins moving again.
Only time will tell. Through the crowd, Steve sees a WOMAN who looks like Mary from the back. fie freezes, then realizes it's not her. Total relief.
The crowd, now even larger, waits.

location: HOWARD'S CAR NEAR THE FAIR GROUNDS

text: Howard searches for a space to park. Every inch of the pl is packed with cars, trucks, buses. Mary prays.
Please let those kids be okay.
A line of cameras fixed on the opening to the hole. At the ambulances, the Teachers stand wrapped in blankets watching, crying. Steve steps a bit closer to the hole with his camera.
Hey! Buddy! Back it up. Steve backs up, refocuses on the hole as the cable rises. - it's one of the Kids Finally, a smiling little face appears being carried up by the Fireman.
They're all okay! The rescuers cheer. The Teachers bawl.
The crowd goes nuts. 93.
Hartman jumps in front of Steve's camera.

Elation here in Louisiana but the danger, far from over as rescuers bring these children up one grubby little face at a time. Hartman looks off to the side, holds up a finger like he' trying not to cry. He signals Steve to cut.
Remind me next time to mention Jesus. Still on the lookout for Mary, Steve's not even listening
Mary and Howard run through the crowd. Mary spots George, the Protestor from Oklahoma and his Wife.
George, Lydia! What's going on? Lydia hugs her.
They got eleven out. All fine, thank God. More coming up.
Steve films as the rescued kids are wrapped in blankets, Teachers hysterically crying. The Fireman brings up another one. As he's raised to grou level he calls out to the Rescue Supervisor.
That's the last of them! As he hands the kid to safety, the cable jerks. He gets o of the basket just in time before the whole thing - baske and cable -- snaps off and drops into the hole. 94.

Mary celebrates with the other onlookers as if she forgot she's there. She glances toward the rescue site and spots Steve on the side. She gets excited all over again, ducks under the ta and runs toward him.
Steve films Hartman.

A happy ending that's left parents across this country wondering - how can I keep my family safe from abandoned mines? Are there abandoned mines in my backyard? Is my child's school built on top of an abandoned mine? Steve spots Mary, running toward him.
No, no, no.
And how, oh how, can these death traps be avoided? Mary drops right into the abandoned mine.
A monitor displays the current broadcast: "Breaking News: Abandoned Mine Accident"
Mary Horowitz. A painful high school photo of Mary appears on the screen Bad hair, bad make-up, ridiculously large smile, unfortun frilly chemise.
A GUY watches the news on his laptop. 95.
Mary Horowitz.
Staff members huddle around the TV.
Mary Horowitz.
As all the other Journalists scramble, Hartman and Steve a bit stunned. Angus joins them, puts his phone on speake

Shame about your girlfriend in the pit, Steve, but we've got the inside advantage here so let's use it. Steve shakes his head, not impressed. Angus takes the phone off speaker, steps aside to talk to Corbitt. Steve's phone rings. He answers it, listens, cringes.
Mrs. Horowitz.
Mrs. Horowitz cries into the phone.
We're coming! Tell her to hang on! Mr. Horowitz runs down the stairs with luggage and Carol gerbil.
